title-group.article-title: The Consequences of Maltreatment on Children’s Lives
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review of Data From the East Asia and Pacific Region

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Deborah Fry, MA, MPH, undertook this research as an individual consultancy funded by the UNICEF East Asia and Pacific Regional Office. She is a Research Fellow at the University of Edinburgh/NSPCC Child Protection Research Centre. At the Centre, she undertakes primary research on the issues of child sexual abuse and youth violence prevention and response. Prior to joining the Centre, she was Research Director at the New York City Alliance Against Sexual Assault. During her time at the Alliance, she was the Principal Investigator (PI) on nine primary research studies on sexual violence and abuse in New York City ranging from participatory action research with immigrant communities to research with young people. She has a Master of Arts degree from the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University and her Master of Public Health degree from Columbia University. She was also a Fulbright Research Scholar from 2001 to 2002. A hallmark of all her research has been working with young people and practitioners—be they school teachers, health clinicians, or social workers—to explore the real-life, day-to-day issues for providing the safest and best environment both to reduce the impact of violence on young people and ultimately to prevent violence from every occurring in the first instance.

Amalee McCoy, MA, MA, is a Child Protection Specialist with the UNICEF East Asia and Pacific Regional Office (EAPRO), based in Bangkok and focusing on policy advocacy and research pertaining to the development of national child protection systems. She has over 10 years of work experience in the areas of child protection and child welfare at the regional level in Asia, as well as at national and local levels in Thailand. Previously, she has worked with Plan International, ECPAT International, and the UN Economic and Social Commission for Asia and Pacific (UNESCAP). She is a dual Thai and U.S. national with an MA in Child and Adolescent Welfare from Charles Sturt University, Australia, and a MA in Southeast Asian Studies from Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS), USA. She is also a former Fulbright recipient.

Diane Swales, DQSW, MA Human Rights, is currently the Regional Advisor for Child Protection in the UNICEF East Asia and Pacific Regional. She comes from a background in Social Work, Fieldwork Practice Education and Assessment, and International Human Rights Law. She has experience in countries across three continents, including in Europe, Africa, and East Asia, with a particular focus on child rights, child care, child welfare, child protection, and justice for children. Her work in these areas is underpinned by a commitment to international human and children’s rights and standards, which are realized in a contextually and culturally appropriate manner.

2United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) East Asia and Pacific Regional Office, Bangkok, Thailand

author-notes.corresp: Deborah Fry, University of Edinburgh/NSPCC Child Protection Research Centre, Moray House, St. Leondard’s Land, Edinburgh EH8 8AQ, UK. Email: Debi.Fry@ed.ac.uk

abstract.p: This study explores the consequences of child maltreatment in East Asia and the Pacific region based on the results of a systematic review of 16 English and non-English databases for journal articles and “gray” literature published between January 2001 and November 2010. This review shows that children in the region experiencing maltreatment are at increased risk of experiencing mental health consequences, physical health sequelae, high-risk sexual behaviors, and increased exposure to future violence including intimate partner violence (IPV) as an adult. Children who suffer from child sexual abuse have a median twofold increased risk of experiencing mental health disorders than those who have never experienced child maltreatment. Similar findings were found for those who experience physical abuse. Children who have been maltreated in the region are also at an increased risk of suicide ideation and attempts than those that have experienced child sexual or physical abuse being at a median fourfold increased risk. Children who have experienced physical abuse or those who have witnessed parental domestic abuse as a child are at median twofold increased risk of experiencing IPV as an adult, while children who have been sexually abused have a median threefold increase in risk of IPV later in life. There are still gaps in our understanding of the consequences of child maltreatment, but we do know that the consequences are profound and far-reaching. The findings indicate that there is an urgent need for governments, civil society organizations, development agencies, and academia to advocate for, invest in, and collaborate across sectors for the strengthening of child protection systems in the East Asia and Pacific Region, with a focus on evidence-based child maltreatment prevention policies and programs.

sec.title: Key Points of the Research Review

list-item.p: There is a growing body of evidence highlighting the negative outcomes of child maltreatment in the East Asia and Pacific region including increased negative health and mental health outcomes, high-risk sexual behaviors and increased exposure to violence.

This review highlights that young people who have experienced child maltreatment in the region are more likely to engage in high risk sexual behaviors such as having more sexual partners in their lifetime, more concurrent sexual partners, and unintended pregnancies.

Adolescents and adults in the region who have experienced child sexual and/or physical abuse have a median fourfold increased risk of suicide ideation and attempts than children without a history of these types of maltreatment.
There is increasing evidence in the region of the links between child maltreatment and subsequent intimate partner violence victimization and perpetration later in life.
Studies included in this review show a cumulative effect on negative outcomes for children who have experienced multiple victimizations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Child maltreatment is prevalent in every society, cutting across class, income, education, culture, and ethnic origin in all countries (U.N. General Assembly, 2006). It is estimated that between a quarter and a half of all children globally reported having experienced severe and frequent physical abuse, while nearly a quarter of women and 5–10% of men reported having experienced child sexual abuse (Krug, Dahlberg, Mercy, Zwi, & Lozano, 2002; Pinheiro, 2006). Adverse and abusive experiences in childhood have been linked to a host of adolescent and adult health sequelae and high-risk behaviors that place the individual’s health and well-being in jeopardy (Gilbert et al., 2009).

Several review studies have shown that individuals who suffer abuse, neglect, or serious family dysfunction as children are more likely to be depressed, to experience other types of psychiatric illnesses and disorders, to engage in more self-injurious behaviors, to have more physical symptoms (both medically explained and unexplained), and to engage in more health-risk behaviors than their nonabused counterparts (Arnow, 2004; Maniglio, 2009). Research also shows that the more severe the abuse, the stronger the association with poor outcomes in adulthood. Childhood sexual abuse in particular has been repeatedly associated with negative physical health outcomes such as pelvic pain and headaches among others (Arnow, 2004).

Data from the National Comorbidity Survey and the Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) study, both nationally representative population studies, indicate a relationship between adverse childhood experiences, such as child sexual abuse and other types of child maltreatment, and the subsequent onset of chronic diseases such as liver disease and autoimmune diseases, psychiatric disorders including depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), social phobias; health risk behaviors such as substance abuse, obesity and high-risk sexual behaviors (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2006; Molnar, Buka, & Kessler, 2001). Findings from the National Comorbity Survey revealed that 78% of women and 82% of men who reported sexual abuse in childhood met criteria for at least one lifetime psychiatric disorder versus 49% and 51%, respectively, among those who did not report child sexual abuse (Molnar et al., 2001).

Several systematic reviews have examined the linkages between child maltreatment and mental health consequences for survivors. In one review of 37 studies (17 case control and 20 cohort), with 3,162,318 participants, a statistically significant association between child sexual abuse and a lifetime diagnosis of anxiety disorder (odds ratio [OR], 3.09; 95% confidence interval [CI]: [2.43, 3.94]), depression (OR, 2.66; 95% CI, [2.14, 3.30]), and PTSD (OR, 2.34; 95% CI, [1.59, 3.43]) was found (Chen et al., 2010). Another systematic review on psychiatric disorders found that approximately 8% of children and adolescents documented as physically abused have current diagnoses of major depressive disorder, approximately 40% have lifetime major depressive disorder diagnoses, and at least 30% have lifetime disruptive disorder diagnoses (oppositional defiant disorder or conduct disorder; Kaplan, Pelcovitz, & Labruna, 1999). Another systematic review found that experiences of child sexual abuse increase vulnerabilities to developing mental health difficulties in adulthood (Hillberg, Hamilton-Giachritsis, & Dixon, 2011).

These associations often persist, regardless of the victim’s sex or the age at which abuse began (Chen et al., 2010). Twin studies provide an opportunity to estimate associations between abuse (where one twin may have experienced abuse while the other did not) while controlling for other adverse family factors. In a study of young adult Australian twins, a history of child sexual abuse was associated with adverse outcomes for females such as depression, alcohol abuse, and society anxiety (Nelson et al., 2002). While the risk of negative mental health outcomes is high, it is important to note that a significant proportion of children may not experience psychopathology following child maltreatment. In a longitudinal study on the Isle of Wight in the United Kingdom, of the 10% of respondents who had experienced physical or sexual abuse in childhood approximately 45% reported no psychopathology over their adult lives. The authors attribute this to the presence of protective factors such as parental care, peer relationships in adolescence, personality, and the quality of adult relationships (Collishaw et al., 2007).

The experience of childhood maltreatment is also associated with increased risk of suicide ideation and attempts (Arnow, 2004). In a meta-analysis of case–control and cohort studies, a fourfold increased association was found between experiencing child sexual abuse and subsequent suicide attempts (OR, 4.14; 95% CI, [2.98, 5.76]; Chen et al., 2010). In the twin study conducted by Nelson and colleagues (2002), the risk of suicide attempt was significantly higher among those with a history of child sexual abuse than among those without such history (Arnow, 2004). In a review of studies exploring domestic violence and child abuse, Herrenkohl, Sousa, Tajima, Herrenkohl, and Moylan (2008) found that the two often co-occur, with the behavioral consequences including an increased risk of attempting suicide among other consequences.

In addition to physical and mental health sequelae, a review by Lalor and McElvaney (2010) found that numerous studies have highlighted that child sexual abuse victims are vulnerable to later sexual revictimization. Classen, Palesh, and Aggarwal (2005) point out that more severe forms of child sexual abuse coupled with experiencing child physical abuse increase the risks of sexual revictimization later in life. Herrenkohl and colleagues (2008) found in their review of domestic violence and child abuse that relational consequences for children often include vulnerability to further victimization or perpetration of violence including intimate partner violence (IPV).

In a systematic review of abuse and neglect research, Kaplan and colleagues (1999) found that aggressive and externalizing behaviors are among the most frequent correlates of physical abuse. This finding is echoed in a recent review of research on the links between child maltreatment and later violence perpetration. This review found evidence of a link between child maltreatment and later violence in youth, although some research is inconclusive as to whether maltreatment is uniquely predictive of outcomes once family and youth demographics and other key variables are taken into account. Physical child abuse appears to be the most consistent predictor of youth violence and other closely related outcomes (e.g., externalizing behaviors and conflict with the law). Sexual abuse and neglect are also potential predictors of violence in youth, although findings are less definitive (Maas, Herrenkohl, & Sousa, 2008).

Despite these global estimates, one of the greatest obstacles to the protection of children from maltreatment in all regions of the world, including the East Asia and Pacific (EAP) region, has been the scarcity of verifiable, national statistical data, as well as robust analysis of the consequences of such maltreatment. The EAP region is one of the most densely populated and culturally diverse regions in the world, containing 37 countries and 580 million children, nearly 27% of the total global child population. Despite the region’s considerable size, it has been a relative latecomer to producing quality research on child maltreatment. Studies as recently as 2005 lauded child abuse as “underreported and under-acknowledged” in the region (Chow, 2005; Qiao & Chan, 2005). Within the last 5 years, the scope of research conducted within the region has increased dramatically. Despite this increase, there are still several countries in the region that have little to no data on the prevalence, incidence, or consequences of child maltreatment. The design and implementation of policies, plans, programs and services to effectively address child maltreatment must be based on scientific evidence; thus, the dearth of valid data in all countries in the region has been a considerable constraint to protecting children.

In addition, mainly due to the paucity of such data, reliable estimates of the consequences and costs of child maltreatment in the region are scarce. Reviews by the World Health Organization (WHO) and others have found that the adverse health outcomes resulting from child abuse, as evidenced in the direct links between child maltreatment and psychological and physical outcomes and high-risk behavior, form a significant portion of the global burden of disease (Krug et al., 2002; Gilbert et al., 2009) with significant economic costs to society (Pinheiro, 2006). Emerging evidence shows that the East Asian region has one of the highest estimated burdens of disease and a high prevalence of child sexual abuse relative to other regions globally (Andrews, Corry, Slade, Issakidis, & Swanston, 2004). Overall, this review found that across the world, child sexual abuse contributed to between 4% and 5% of the burden of disease in males and between 7% and 8% of the burden of disease in females for depression, alcohol abuse/dependence, and drug abuse/dependence. The attributable fractions were higher for panic disorder (7% for males and 13% for females) and higher still for PTSD (21% for males and 33% for females). For suicide attempts, attributable fractions were 6% for males and 11% for females (Andrews et al., 2004). It should be emphasized that this burden is borne not only by affected children and their families but also by society at large, as reflected in related costs for medical services, child protection services and out-of-home care, lost labor productivity, incarceration and treatment of offenders, law enforcement responses, those incurred through prosecution of perpetrators within the judicial system, and contributions from community volunteers and civil society organizations.

To date, no research has systematically reviewed all the published and unpublished research that has been conducted on the consequences of child maltreatment in the EAP Region. To get a sense of the wider impact of child maltreatment on society, as well as the individual child, this systematic review focuses on research that has examined the outcomes and consequences of child maltreatment in the region. This research will serve as the foundation for a future meta-analysis of the data and the development of a costing model for the EAP Region on child maltreatment in order to inform policies and programs to respond to and prevent child maltreatment.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: This systematic review examined peer-reviewed journal articles and unpublished gray literature produced from January 2000 to November 2010 on the consequences of child maltreatment in the region. A comprehensive search of 16 databases including PubMed/Medline, ProQuest, PsycINFO, ScienceDirect, CINAHL-ebsco, EMBASE, ERIC, NCJRS, Violence and Abuse Abstracts, Social Work Abstracts, SocIndex, Family and Society Studies Worldwide, Google, Google Scholar, SSCI, and Korea Med was undertaken using the keywords and synonyms for “child,” “abuse/maltreatment,” and the country name. In addition, articles from the last 10 years were reviewed from the journals of Child Abuse and Neglect, Child Maltreatment, Child Abuse Review, and Journal of Interpersonal Violence. The ninth edition of the World Perspectives on Child Abuse published by the International Society for Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect (ISPCAN) was also reviewed as well as a manual search of the references in this publication for additional articles and reports that met the inclusion criteria.

There is at least one country in the region (China) that produces a large number of primary research reports and articles in their original language. Many of these articles and reports are unlikely to be indexed in primarily English-speaking databases as the ones listed above. To address this issue, the reviewer consulted with researchers in China to ensure that there was coverage of Chinese language primary research articles in the review. In total, the researcher consulted with over 20 regional experts. Overall, 18 articles and reports were translated from their original language into English and included in this review.

This article represents one aspect of a larger systematic review that examined the prevalence and incidence of child maltreatment in addition to the consequences of maltreatment in the EAP region. The findings from the data on the prevalence and incidence are presented elsewhere. The larger review yielded a vast literature of over 6,000 articles and reports from the initial search. The online abstract was retrieved and reviewed against the inclusion criteria (Table 1) to select articles for the review. The larger review examined data presented at conferences and through dissertations but this article will focus on the findings from peer-reviewed journal articles and gray literature from the region. Figure 1 highlights the number of studies from the initial search and the articles included and excluded in the review.

list-item.p: Primary research on the prevalence, incidence, and consequences of child maltreatment in the East Asia and Pacific region
Peer-reviewed and non peer-reviewed journal articles, presentations, dissertations, or research reports

Geographic focus in East Asia and Pacific Region encompassing the following countries and territories: Brunei Darussalem, Cambodia, China, Cook Islands, Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, Fiji, Indonesia, Japan, Kiribati, Republic of Korea, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Republic of the Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nauru, Niue, Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands, Republic of Palau, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Samoa, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Thailand, Timor-Leste, Tokelau, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu, and Viet Nam.
Research published in English or any of the languages of the countries in the East Asia and Pacific region

sec.p: Studies where the population was sampled on the basis of the presence of one of the consequences variables were excluded from this study. The reason to exclude sampling based on presence or absence of an outcome variable is that these cannot be used to calculate a relative risk of those outcomes (Steiner 1998 as cited in Andrews et al., 2004). Therefore, in this review, case–control studies were only included if the “cases” are individuals exposed to one or more of the child maltreatment variables and “controls” are those who are not exposed (Andrews et al., 2004). Full details of the search strategy, search terms used, and excluded articles are available from the author.

A data extraction tool was utilized to extract bibliographical details and descriptive data about each study included in the review. In addition to data abstraction, each article was reviewed for potential bias. For quantitative cross-sectional studies, risk of bias was measured by examining three key areas: sampling, measurement, and analysis (Boyle, 1998). For case control and cohort studies, the “Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of nonrandomized studies in meta-analyses” was used (Wells et al., 2010). This scale examines research studies in three categories: selection, comparability, and exposure. A study can receive a maximum of one star for each numbered item within the first two categories (Selection and Exposure) and a maximum of two stars can be given for each item in the Comparability section. For other studies that fell outside the range of these quality assessment tools (such as secondary data analysis or clinical case reviews), the key variables of setting, study design, biases/limitations reported, and outcomes were documented on the data abstraction form. To assess qualitative research, the tested assessment tool called Critical Review Form—Qualitative Studies (version 2.0) was used (Letts et al., 2007). This tool looks at several important criteria for measuring the quality of qualitative data such as clarity of study purpose, appropriateness of study design, sampling, procedural rigor, analytical rigor, auditability, credibility, transferability, and dependability.

sec.title: Methodological Limitations
sec.p: Every effort has been made to reduce the risk of bias in this systematic review. Despite this, several limitations exist. First, the articles were assessed against the inclusion criteria, included or excluded and reviewed by one author. In order to combat this known limitation from the start, a Regional Advisory Committee brought together by UNICEF East Asia and Pacific Regional Office (EAPRO) to inform the development of a regional costing model on the minimum lifetime costs of child maltreatment, reviewed and commented on the research protocol and drafts of the findings from the systematic review. Second, research conducted in languages other than English may be underrepresented. Efforts were made to contact international experts in countries in the region for additional help in identifying literature in languages other than English. The abstract or titles of the articles were often in English and indexed in the academic databases, but the full-text versions would be inaccessible. The author worked with researchers and translators in China specifically to access full-text versions of academic articles and to translate the findings into English. Even greater limitations may exist on the comprehensiveness of the gray literature research included in the review. Key organizational websites and international and local nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) were accessed to identify literature but gaps in non-English gray literature most certainly exist.

sec.title: Overall
sec.p: A total of 106 studies were identified that met the inclusion criteria. Table 2 highlights key information such as location, sample size, measures of child maltreatment, study design, sampling methods, sample groups, sampling location, risk of bias in the individual studies and key maltreatment and consequences variables that were studied. Of these, the vast majority were quantitative studies. Forty-three studies (40%) utilized probability sampling and the remainder utilized convenience sampling. Additionally, 10 studies were case–control studies and only six studies were qualitative. Studies were identified from 16 countries including 6 Pacific Island countries and one territory in the region with 34% of the studies conducted in China, 14% in Japan, 13% in the Republic of Korea, and 3% in the Philippines. Thirty-nine studies (37%) utilized researcher-developed questions to measure different types of child maltreatment, 14 studies used some form of the Conflict Tactics scale (CTS, CTS2, CTSPC), and the remainder of studies utilized measures as identified in Table 2.

sec.p: Findings on the consequences of child maltreatment are grouped into five main categories: (1) mental health consequences which include depression, anxiety, suicide ideation, etc., (2) physical health outcomes, (3) sexual health which includes risky sexual behaviors, (4) IPV outcomes which include victimization and perpetration, and (5) other behaviors which include both other violence outcomes but also other risky behaviors such as substance misuse and eating disorders.

sec.title: Overall mental health
sec.p: Fifty-four studies in the review focused on the mental health consequences of child maltreatment. The majority of these concentrated on either overall mental health outcomes or specific mental health outcomes such as depression and anxiety for the key child maltreatment variables, including severe physical abuse, contact and noncontact child sexual abuse, emotional abuse, and witnessing parental domestic violence. Table 3 highlights the findings by country of studies that used mental health disorder classification systems such as the Symptom Checklist-90 (SCL-90) or the ICD-10 diagnostic criteria to measure consequences outcome variables. The SCL-90 is a 90 item self-report inventory used to measure current (i.e., past 7 days) psychiatric symptoms. Specifically, it measures psychological symptoms such as somatization, obsessive–compulsive, interpersonal sensitivity, depression, anxiety, hostility, phobic anxiety, paranoid ideation, and psychoticism. These can be assessed and are summarized into an overall score. Specific cutoffs have been developed by specialists to determine what level could be clinically considered to have a common mental disorder. ICD-10 diagnostic criteria are a similar tool to determine mental and behavioral disorders.

sec.p: In a randomized college sample that compared students who had reported experiencing child sexual abuse with a national youth group on the Symptom Checklist-90 (SCL-90), it was found that scores in the basis symptom factors of the SCL-90 test were higher in students who had experienced child sexual abuse than in the national youth group. Significant differences were found between the two groups in symptoms of somatization, obsessive–compulsive, and psychoticism (Sun et al., 2008). Overall, findings from this review show that children who suffer from child sexual abuse have a median twofold increased risk of experiencing mental health disorders than those who have never experienced child maltreatment. Similar findings have found a relationship between child neglect, child physical abuse, child sexual abuse, and exposure to domestic violence during childhood, with onset of mental disorders and common mental disorders (Jirapramukpitak, Harpham, & Prince, 2010; Jirapramukpitak, Prince, & Harpham, 2005; Ma et al., 2005; Sun et al., 2008; Yen, Yang, Chen, et al., 2008).

sec.title: Depression and anxiety
sec.p: Several research studies have shown the relationship between child sexual abuse and depression. In a study of 892 female medical students in China, researchers found that compared to the students who had not experienced child sexual abuse, the students who had experienced child sexual abuse reported higher levels of depression on a depression screening tool (Chen, Han, & Dunne, 2004). A similar relationship between abuse and depression was found in a study of male high school students. In this study, the male students who reported experiencing child fsexual abuse had higher scores of depression on clinical measurements and lower self-esteem when compared to the students who had no history of child sexual abuse (Chen, Dunne, & Wang, 2003).

Several studies have examined the associations between anxiety and child maltreatment with mixed results. In a clinical case–control examining parental verbal abuse in Japan, researchers found that as expected, subjects who experienced parental verbal abuse had substantially higher levels of anxiety, depression, somatization, and anger-hostility than those who did not experience parental verbal abuse. Altogether, 48% of the subjects who had experienced parental verbal abuse had a history of mood disorders, and 24% had a history of anxiety disorders (Tomoda et al., 2010). This history was also found in another case–control study (cases were those with a history of childhood physical abuse and controls were those without a history) of outpatients visiting a hospital for psychosomatic symptoms in Japan, where researchers found that a history of childhood physical abuse was reported by patients with depressive disorders (12.7%) and anxiety disorders (16.7%). Several different types of anxiety were higher in the abused group than in the nonabused group (Handa, Nukina, Hosoi, & Kubo, 2008).

Though anxiety may be influenced by other factors, a study of university students in Japan found (through structural equation modeling) that witnessing family violence failed to add significant contribution in predicting anxiety or depression. The authors found that although witnessing family violence is correlated with anxiety and depression, it loses its significance when controlling for the effects of angry feelings and expression (Kitamura & Hasui, 2006).

Self-esteem, or a person’s overall appraisal of his or her own self-worth, significantly impacts all areas of functioning. Like depression, sadness, and anxiety, studies have shown that child maltreatment can have an adverse impact on children’s and adult’s self-esteem. Two qualitative studies with children in the review have found an emerging theme of low self-esteem in research on parental verbal abuse (Esteban, 2006; Figer, 2008).

sec.title: Dissociation
sec.p: Abuse and exploitation are traumatic events and coping with these experiences is typically difficult, especially for children. “Escaping” or disassociating oneself from the event has also been found to be a common coping strategy for survivors of abuse. In a study of Korean children removed from their homes due to maltreatment and place in Child Protective Services, three specific coping strategies that the children used emerged: (1) accepting the maltreatment; (2) escaping; and (3) secretly crying and trying to endure by keeping silent (Ju & Lee, 2010). A life-history study of 11 survivors of child sexual abuse in Taiwan, China, found that dissociation shielded the participants from the overwhelming memory of child sexual abuse. Dissociation also made it possible for participants with a higher educational level to succeed academically (Chien, 2007).

sec.title: Suicide ideation/attempts and self-harm
sec.p: Table 4 highlights studies that have explored the relationship between child violence and suicide ideation in both children and adults. These studies especially highlight the linkages between child sexual abuse, physical abuse, and suicide ideation for both males and females. Children who have been maltreated in the region are at an increased risk of suicide ideation and attempts with those that have experienced child sexual or physical abuse having a median fourfold increased risk.

sec.p: The relationship between child sexual abuse, physical abuse, and suicide ideation exists for several different age groups, including middle school students. The rate of self-harm from the Xiao and colleagues (2008) study of middle school students (n = 10,894) was 22.3% for physically maltreated students. A dose–response trend existed between the number of items of repeated serious childhood physical abuse, moderate childhood physical abuse, and childhood emotional abuse with rates of general self-injurious behaviors. Another study with middle school students in China (Wong et al., 2009) found that those with a history of either physical maltreatment or child sexual abuse were, respectively, 2 times and 3.5 times more likely to have suicide ideation than students without the history of physical or sexual abuse. A study of eighth-grade (Form 2) students in Hong Kong found that those who reported having ever been beaten to the point of injury by a family member were 5 times more likely to ever think of hurting themselves than other students (Lau, Chan, Lam, Choi, & Lai, 2003).

The association between child sexual abuse, physical abuse, and suicide continues to be seen in high school populations in the region. In a matched case control study of 90 technical secondary students in Xuzhou city in Henan province, China, (Zhu et al., 2007), researchers found that compared to those who had not experienced physical abuse, the abused students had higher percentages of having suicide ideation in the past week (14.4% vs. 2.2%, χ2 = 7.27, p < .01) and in the past year (32.2% vs. 14.4%, χ2 = 13.12, p < .01). More of them attempted suicide (15.6% vs. 3.3%, χ2 = 6.50, p < 0105). A study in the Republic of Korea of over 1,000 high school students found that both males and females with a history of physical abuse, which consisted of an adult hitting them with something or attacking them more than 2 times in the past, were more likely to report suicide ideation over the 2 weeks preceding the survey (OR, 6.52; 95% CI [3.36, 12.63] and OR, 1.97; 95% CI [1.08, 3.57], respectively; Park, Schepp, Jang, & Koo, 2006).

These studies also highlight that the relationship between child physical abuse, sexual abuse, and suicide ideation continues into young adulthood. In a study of 892 female medical students in China, the students who had experienced child sexual abuse were more likely to report ever seriously having considered attempted suicide (23.7% vs. 15.4%, χ2 = 8.09, p = .004) and making a plan about how they would attempt suicide (17.9% vs. 9.7%, χ2 = 10.62, p = .001) than students who had not experienced child sexual abuse (Chen, Han, & Dunne, 2004). This study also found that the relationship with suicide ideation existed for females that experienced both contact and noncontact child sexual abuse. In a household survey with adolescents and adults in Hong Kong, China, it was found that those who reported a history of child sexual abuse were 7 times more likely to report suicide ideation than those who did not report a history of child sexual abuse (OR 7.477; 95% CI [2.839, 19.6]). This relationship still remained strong after controlling for other factors that may influence suicide ideation such as gender, age, alcohol, and drug abuse (Chan, Yan, Brownridge, Tiwari, & Fong, 2010).

Witnessing parental domestic violence as a child also increases the risk of suicide ideation in adolescents in the region. In a longitudinal study in the Philippines with 17- to 19-year-olds (Hindin & Gultiano, 2006), it was found that for both males and females, those who had witnessed parental domestic violence were significantly more likely to report depressive symptoms. In this study, 11% of young men and 19% of young women reported wishing that they were dead occasionally or most of the time, and 7% of young men thought about taking their own life. In addition, 31% of young women thought they were worthless, 21% of young women thought life was not worth living, and nearly half of all respondents recalled parental domestic violence. Another population-based household survey in China found that those who reported witnessing parental psychological aggression in childhood were nearly 3 times more likely to also report suicide ideation than those who did not witness such aggression (Chan et al., 2010).

In addition to suicide ideation, strong linkages have been found between histories of child maltreatment and future suicide attempts. In a qualitative study with suicide attempters aged 15 to 24 who had been consecutively hospitalized from August 2001 to August 2003 in the Intensive Care Unit at the Socson District Hospital in Viet Nam, the young persons reflected that personal conflict was the main motive of attempted suicide for 18 suicide attempters, and that 10 of the young suicide attempters were regularly beaten by their parents. An additional 16 of the suicide attempters were psychologically abused by their families for at least 1 year before attempting suicide, incurring regular scolding, blame, and criticism, or being reproached in ways that made them feel guilty and sad (Wasserman et al., 2008).

In addition to self-harm through suicide attempts, studies have shown a relationship between other self-harm behaviors and a history of child maltreatment. In a study of 10,894 junior and senior secondary students in China, researchers found that students with a history of severe physical abuse were more likely to report engaging in self-harm behaviors, such as banging their head, cutting their wrist, swallowing inedible things, cutting the body, and reporting any self-harm behavior, than students without a history of severe physical abuse. This relationship had a dose–response effect, meaning that the more episodes they reported of severe physical abuse in their childhood, the more likely their odds of engaging in the self-harm behaviors (Xiao, Tao, et al., 2008).

sec.title: Physical Health
sec.p: An immediate consequence of child maltreatment (including physical and/or sexual abuse) is adverse physical health and injuries. Other immediate health consequences for all types of child maltreatment include chronic consequences, such as chronic daily headaches (Juan, Wang, Fuh, Lu, & Chen, 2004), stomach pain, shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, irregular menstruation, sleep disturbances (Wong, Leung, Tang, et al., 2009), genitourinary symptoms (Luo, Parish, & Laumann, 2008), and psychosomatic disorders (Masuda et al., 2007). In addition to specific health consequences, this review found that children and young people who have experienced child maltreatment rate their overall health as poorer than those who have not experienced child abuse (Chen, 2004; Chen, Han, & Dunne, 2004; Chen, Wang, & Dunne, 2003; Yen, Yang, Chen, et al., 2008; ).

Research is also beginning to show that there may be actual changes to the brain matter as a result of child maltreatment. A clinical case–control study in Japan (Kitayama et al., 2007) found that there were no differences in total area of the corpus callosum or in individual subregions, but that the subregion/total area ratio was significantly smaller in posterior midbody in subjects with PTSD compared to the healthy subjects. Another clinical case–control study (Tomoda et al., 2010) examining parental verbal abuse in Japan showed that exposure to parental verbal abuse was associated with alterations in the left superior temporal gyrus (STG/BA22). This region plays a critical role in processing of language and speech. A similar study found that the Plasma neuropeptide Y (NPY), a neurotransmitter in the brain that is responsible for several physiologic processes including the regulation of energy balance, memory and learning, and epilepsy, has been found to be significantly lower in child sexual abuse victims than in controls. The results indicate that female victims of child sexual abuse could have memory and execution impairments. The decreased plasma NPY level may play a role in the memory impairment, but it is not related to the severity of posttraumatic stress symptoms (Huang et al., 2005).

Three additional studies in the review highlight that experiencing child sexual abuse impacts on females’ memory, execution, and attention abilities. Loss of memory was found in a case–control study of female inmates in China, which found that both long-term and short-term memory among the group that had experienced child sexual abuse were significantly lower than those in the control group, showing a potential link between experiencing child sexual abuse and memory loss (Huang et al., 2005). Other results from the case–control study of female inmates in China found that, based on execution and attention test scores, child sexual abuse victims had to take the test more and made more errors, as well as achieved a lower score on the attention test, than the controls who had not experienced child sexual abuse (Huang et al., 2005). These findings have also been found in a study of university students from Japan and the United States, which indicated that a substantial proportion of participants reporting childhood abuse perpetrated by someone close to them also reported associated memory disruption and psychological distress (Allard, 2009).

sec.title: Sexual Health
sec.p: The study by Luo and colleagues (2008) looked at a whole range of consequences as a result of child sexual abuse and found that men who had experienced child sexual abuse were more likely to have concurrent partners, were more likely to have sex to please a partner, and were more likely to fear being harassed than men without a history of child sexual abuse. Likewise, there were several associations for women as well, including having more sexual partners both during their lifetime and in the past year, and also being more fearful of being harassed, than women who have not experienced child sexual abuse (Luo, Parish, & Laumann, 2008).

A study of 1,068 adults in Manila, Philippines, found that adults with a history of psychological abuse or psychological neglect were more likely to have an unintended pregnancy than those without the history of abuse or neglect, after controlling for age, sex, socioeconomic status, and education (Ramiro, Madrid, & Brown, 2010). This study also found that adults with a history of child sexual abuse were more than 8 times more likely to have an early pregnancy (under the age of 18) than those without a history of child sexual abuse (Adjusted Odds Ratio [AOR], 8.5; 95% CI [3.9, 18.6]).

sec.title: IPV
sec.p: There is a growing evidence base in the EAP region highlighting the links between child maltreatment, specifically child sexual abuse or witnessing parental domestic violence and subsequent IPV—both victimization and perpetration. Tables 5 and 6 highlight the findings from studies in this review on these associations. This review found that children who have experienced physical abuse or those who have witnessed parental domestic abuse as a child are at twofold increased risk of experiencing IPV as an adult, while children who have been sexually abused have a threefold increase in risk of IPV later in life.

sec.p: In a study of female medical students in China, researchers found that females with a history of contact sexual abuse (i.e., molestation and forced sex) were over 5 times more likely to have been hit, slapped, or physically hurt on purpose by their boyfriend or girlfriend in the last 12 months, than females who had not experienced child sexual abuse (Chen, Dunne, & Han, 2006). The Japan portion of the WHO multi-country study on women’s health and domestic violence (Yoshihama & Horrocks, 2010) also found a significant relationship between child sexual abuse and sexual initiation, and the subsequent risk of IPV among women of Japan, with this finding being consistent with studies conducted in the other countries. However, a study of newly married couples in China (Zou et al., 2007) found that respondents with experience of IPV in the past year reported significantly higher scores for emotional, physical, and overall abuse scores during childhood, but not for sexual abuse and neglect scores.

This relationship to subsequent IPV appears to be especially strong for children who have witnessed domestic violence as a child. In a representative study of over 800 married women in Bangkok, Thailand (Kerley, Xu, Sirisunyaluck, & Alley, 2010), authors found that Thai women who were exposed to family violence as children tend to respond violently as well in adult family contexts. In a representative Korean study, women with a history of parental verbal or physical violence were 1½ half times more likely to experience physical violence by a partner than women without this history of witnessing domestic violence (Kim, Park, & Emery, 2009). A study in the Philippines found that young adults with a history of witnessing mother perpetrated domestic violence against their father in childhood are 4 times more likely to be victimized by partner violence in the last year than those who did not witness domestic violence (Fehringer & Hindin, 2009). In a study of 1,399 university students in the Republic of Korea, Gover, Park, Tomsich, and Jennings (2010) found that witnessing mother-to-father violence was significantly related to physical violence victimization for males (b = 0.66. SE = 0.15, p < .001).

In a study on domestic violence in Myanmar (Kyu & Kanai, 2005), researchers compared women who had and had not witnessed parental violence as a child. The women who witnessed parental violence often or very often reported more minor physical assaults than those who have never witnessed parental violence. Moreover, the women who witnessed parental violence often/very often reported more minor and severe psychological aggression than those who rarely or never witnessed parental violence. The researchers found no effect of witnessing parental violence on severe physical assault. The researchers found through the analysis of variance that except for severe physical assault, the women who witnessed and experienced parental violence often/very often had the highest domestic violence tendencies among all other groups. However, the results also indicated that when other factors were controlled for, witnessing parental violence as a child had a significant effect on minor psychological aggression only, and that for all other forms of IPV the characteristics of the husband had a much greater impact on the likelihood of the woman experiencing violence (Kyu & Kanai, 2005).

sec.title: Other Behaviors
sec.p: In addition to mental and physical health, studies in the region have explored other behavioral relationships with child maltreatment such as substance abuse, early initiation into smoking, violence and aggression, and eating disorders.

sec.title: Eating disorders
sec.p: Recent research in the region has shown the associations between child maltreatment and eating disorders among adolescents. A study of high school students in China found that females with a history of both noncontact and contact child sexual abuse were approximately 3 times more likely to have vomited or taken laxatives to lose weight or to keep from gaining weight than females without a history of child sexual abuse (Chen, Dunne, & Han, 2004). This consequence was actually more pronounced for males who had a history of contact child sexual abuse—these male high school students were over 7 times more likely to vomit or use laxatives to lose weight or keep from gaining weight than males without a history of child sexual abuse.

Other associations have been found with eating habits and weight. For example, a survey of junior high school students in China found that those students with a history of physical maltreatment were more likely to have poor appetites (Wong et al., 2009), and a study in the Philippines among adults found that those with a history of child sexual abuse were more likely to weigh over or equal to 170 lbs than other adults in the study without the history of child sexual abuse (Ramiro et al., 2010).

sec.title: Substance misuse and early smoking initiation
sec.p: Alcohol use has been linked in a variety of ways to child maltreatment—from early drinking age to problem drinking and marrying an alcoholic—with several studies from the region starting to highlight these associations (Chen, Dunne, & Han, 2004; Jirapramukpitak et al., 2010; Jirapramukpitak et al., 2005; Ramiro et al., 2010; Wakai, Miura, & Umenai, 2005; Xiao, Dong, Yao, Li, & Ye, 2008; Yen, Yang, Chen, et al., 2008). Problem drinking appears to be an especially strong association. In a study of young residents in Northern Bangkok, it was found that those with a history of penetrative (oral, anal, and/or vaginal) sexual abuse before the age of 16 were 19 times more likely to report problem drinking habits than young adults without a history of child sexual abuse (Jirapramukpitak, Prince, & Harpham, 2005). A similar association between experiencing child physical abuse and a higher likelihood of problem drinking was found in a study of junior high school students in China (Yen, Yang, Chen, et al., 2008).

Early smoking initiation and ever smoking as a child have been linked to child maltreatment. In a study of 892 female medical students in China, Chen, Han, and Dunne (2004) found that compared to the students who had not experienced child sexual abuse, students who had experienced child sexual abuse were more likely to report having ever smoked during the past 30 days (smoking 8.8% vs. 4.4%, χ2 = 6.17, p = .013).

sec.title: Aggression
sec.p: Studies are also beginning to show the linkages between child maltreatment, specifically harsh or severe corporal punishment, and subsequent adolescent and adult aggression. In a study of grade 4 children in a Hong Kong primary school, Chang, Lansford, Schwartz, and Farver (2004) found that severe punishment was positively associated with child externalizing, meaning that the more severe the punishment by parents, the more likely the child was to act out in other ways. In another study of two kindergartens in Hong Kong, China, Chang, Schwartz, Dodge, and McBride-Chang (2003) found that harsh parenting from both mothers and fathers affected child emotion regulation, which, in turn, led to school aggression. These effects were significant. Fathers’ harsh parenting also had a significant effect on child aggression. One anthropological fieldwork study highlighted the relationship between experiencing violence from fathers and grandfathers and future aggression among boys in Viet Nam (Rydstrøm, 2006).

Similar findings were found in a Singapore study of preschool children and their parents, but with an exploration of the type of punishment and its effect on aggression (Sim & Ong, 2005). In another study of adolescent Filipino students (Maxwell & Maxwell, 2003), researchers found that child-directed and child-witnessed violence influence adolescent aggression. This direct and positive relationship remains even while controlling for several other factors that are commonly used to explain antisocial behavior and/or delinquency. The effects of both family violence measures on aggression also do not vary by gender, suggesting that both forms of family violence have similar negative consequences for both boys’ and girls’ levels of aggression. The findings also showed that of the two family violence measures examined, witnessing violence had the largest observed effect on children’s aggression.

sec.title: Antisocial and disruptive behavior
sec.p: In addition to aggressive behaviors, research in the region has focused on linkages between child abuse and violence victimization, and other antisocial and disruptive behaviors. In a study with grade six children in the Philippines, Maxwell (2001) found that there was a linkage between a specific indicator of familial strain (witnessing violence) on varying levels of the children's self-reported antisocial behaviors, and the teacher's predictions score (of their student’s behaviors), which is an independent measure of antisocial behavior. This relationship holds even when indicators of social control (measures of commitment to family, respect for authority, and moral beliefs) and peer associations were controlled. Surprisingly, parent-to-child aggression, which has been found in many Western studies to have an important effect, was not significant in any of the models tested in this study (Maxwell, 2001). Child abuse also has associations with child disruptive behavior disorders (DBD). In a clinical study of 144 patients receiving routine outpatient treatment for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD; Bandou, Koike, & Matuura, 2010), it was found that child abuse and parental psychiatric disorders were likely to have strong associations with comorbid disruptive behavioral disorders.

Several studies in the region have shown linkages between child maltreatment and other violence perpetration—specifically on violence within school settings. In a study of 892 female medical students in China, Chen, Han, and Dunne (2004) found that compared to the students who had not experienced child sexual abuse, the students who had experienced child sexual abuse were more involved in physical fights (16.7% vs. 5.6% χ2 = 27.05, p = .000) in the 12 months preceding the survey. Similarly, a study of 201 Japanese students (in a larger sample of 812 university students from Japan, South Africa, and the United States) by Dussich and Maekoya (2007) found that there are significant relationships between physical child harm and three types of bullying related behaviors: offending, being victimized, and offending plus being victimized. Using social coping theory, this research suggests that the manner in which physically harmed children cope with their early victimization has a bearing on their subsequent involvement with bullying-related behaviors.

However, a study that looked at pathways to various behaviors (Chen & Astor, 2011) found that this link between childhood experiences of abuse and perpetrating violence may be mediated through other factors. This study found that students’ prior victimization has direct links to both violence against other students and violence against teachers in school settings. Prior victimization also has indirect effects on violence against students mediated through school engagement and risky peers, and indirect effects on violence against teachers mediated through all school variables (school engagement, risky peers, and student–teacher interactions). Therefore, there may be other factors involved in mediating these consequences. In another study among high school students in the city of Taegu, Republic of Korea (Morash & Moon, 2007), researchers found that the combination of the experience of abuse by teachers and having peers who engage in illegal activities and/or are in conflict with the law are the strongest predictors of violence perpetration for both girls and boys. Another study in the Republic of Korea found that the biggest risk factor for perpetrating bullying and violent behaviors in school may be experiencing bullying. This study utilized a representative random sample of middle school students and found that prior bullying victimization experience is the single most important factor that increases bullying behaviors in all levels (Lee, 2010).

Only one study examined the link between child abuse and children’s violence against animals. In a case–control study of maltreated and nonmaltreated children in Japan, Yamazaki (2010) found that the maltreated children were more likely to witness and perpetrate more serious animal abuse, compared to those in the nonmaltreated group. altreated children reported worries such as their animals being killed or abused—worries that were not reported by those in the nonmaltreated group. Thus, generally, the results imply that maltreated children sought more support from animals as portrayed by the array of positive experiences they had, but at the same time, they also experienced more violence involving animals.

In addition to violence perpetration, studies in this review have shown that a potential consequence of experiencing child maltreatment is other violence victimization from peers and partners. In a study of 892 female medical students in China, Chen, Han, and Dunne (2004) found that compared to the students who had not experienced child sexual abuse, those who had experienced child sexual abuse were over 6 times more likely to be threatened or injured by someone with a weapon such as a knife or club on school property (3.5% vs. 1.1%, χ2 = 6.17, p = .013) in the 12 months preceding the survey.

This link between experiencing childhood sexual abuse and experiencing further victimization was highlighted in several studies from the region. Among college students in Shanghai, China, researchers found that those respondents who had ever experienced child sexual abuse before the age of 14 years had also reported more experiences of sexual intercourse and forced sexual intercourse later than those who had not experienced child sexual abuse (Niu, Lou, Gao, Zuo, & Shah, 2010). A study of nearly 3,000 men and women in an urban China study found that women with any childhood sexual contact abuse were over 4 times more likely to also experience physical sexual harassment, and nearly 3 times more likely to experience verbal sexual harassment, than women without this history of contact child sexual abuse (Luo, Parish, & Laumann, 2008).

sec.title: Polyvictimization
sec.p: Polyvictims, or those that have experienced multiple types of victimizations, often experience more severe consequences. In a convenience sample of secondary students, Nguyen, Dunne, and Lee (2010) conducted statistical tests to examine multiple experiences of maltreatment and their effect on adolescents’ mental health. It was found that the effects of experiencing multiple forms of maltreatment were large and statistically significant, especially for depression, and more moderate effects were found with anxiety and self-esteem. Furthermore, there was a dose–response effect, meaning the more maltreatment a child experienced, the more the effects would be seen. A similar dose–response effect was found in a study of 5,141 middle school students in China that used the SCL-90. This study found that the more types of repeat abuse experienced, such as serious child physical abuse, moderate child physical abuse, and child emotional abuse, the greater the rates of general mental problems and psychopathological symptoms (Tao et al., 2006).

All of these findings reinforce the concept of polyvictimization or the notion that children that have been maltreated are at particular risk of and often experience further victimizations (Finkelhor, Ormrond, & Turner, 2007). A randomized household survey study in Japan (Fujiwara, Kawakami, & WMHJSG, 2010) found that high comorbidity was confirmed: among those who reported to have at least one childhood adversity (CA), 32% reported to have other CAs. The mean number of additional CAs was 3 among those who experienced either childhood physical or sexual abuse (Fujiwara, Kawakami, & WMHJSG, 2010). Similar patterns were found for children who experienced neglect with nearly 9 of the 10 (89.5%) reporting additional CAs (mean number of 3), and for those who have experienced family violence, 1 in 2 (50.1%) experienced further adversities such as abuse.

Other studies have found similar findings. A study by Chaopricha and Jurapramukpitak (2010) of a population-based survey with 488 young people aged 16–25 years in Thailand, 6.5% reported experiencing two types of abuse (which included physical abuse, sexual abuse, witnessing domestic violence, or experiencing partner violence), and a further 1.5% had experienced three types of abuse. Not only does maltreatment and abuse put children at risk of further abuse, the additional abuse starts a cycle of additional consequences. For example, in a study of university students in Japan, researchers found that the relative risk of psychosomatic disorder was increased by 2.5 times in those who had one or two intrafamilial adverse childhood experiences (such as physical or sexual abuse, neglect, etc.; 95% CI: [1.4, 4.0]; p < .01), and by 3.0 times (95% CI: [1.9, 4.4]; p < .01) in those who had three or more intrafamilial adverse childhood experiences (Masuda et al., 2007). In a household survey in the Philippines examining adverse childhood experiences (Ramiro et al., 2010), it was found that 100% of the respondents who reported experiencing adverse childhood experiences (including abuse) reported also experiencing an additional two adverse experiences. These findings are similar for those who reported experiencing sexual abuse, with 75% reporting an additional two adverse childhood experiences, and 71.7% of those reporting they had experienced physical neglect also reporting multiple adverse experiences.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This review highlights the growing evidence that child maltreatment has severe and often cumulative consequences for children and adults in the EAP region. To date, the research on consequences of child maltreatment in the region has focused primarily on mental health consequences of child maltreatment. There is a strong evidence base highlighting the link between suicide ideation and attempts with child maltreatment in the region. The findings of this review echo findings from a meta-analysis of case–control and cohort studies that have shown that those who have experienced child sexual abuse are at a fourfold increased risk of suicidal ideation and attempted suicide (Chen et al., 2010). What this review also highlights is that the same risk exists for children who have experienced physical abuse. Furthermore, the relationships found between child sexual and physical abuse and suicide ideation do not exist just for young adults but persist across the entire life span, from middle school through to adulthood.

In addition to mental health outcomes, this review has highlighted the increasing research in the region that has explored the linkages between child maltreatment and IPV in later life. Studies in this review have highlighted that experiences of child maltreatment are potential risk factors for both IPV perpetration and victimization as an adult. However, the studies showed a higher median risk of subsequent intimate partner victimization.

In the larger review, exploitation was also examined as an additional form of child maltreatment. Research on exploitation, for example—trafficking for sexual purposes, engagement in the worst forms of child labor, and treatment of children in conflict with the law—has clearly shown the impact on education, working conditions, and livelihoods of this form of child maltreatment. No research was identified for other forms of child maltreatment that explored these impacts. Further research is needed to establish the correlations between childhood experiences of various forms of maltreatment and their effects on outcomes such as academic achievement, school enrolment and retention, and grade repetition, as well as labor force participation, labor productivity, and earnings during adulthood.

This systematic review is the first step toward gaining a better understanding of the potential impact of child maltreatment across the EAP region. Perhaps, what is most telling is what research is not being conducted. Overall, there is a lack of studies conducted in the lower income countries in the region. Research has shown that child maltreatment tends to be higher in lower income countries or those countries with the greatest income inequalities (Krug et al., 2002), so it is likely that more children in these countries are experiencing the negative sequelae of abuse. More research is needed on the burden of child maltreatment in these countries to obtain a better understanding of the impact on the region as a whole.

What is clear from this review is that a significant number of children in the region are suffering severe and often multiple consequences as a result of child maltreatment. While it is difficult if not impossible to generalize, given the great diversity and complexity of societies and cultures in the EAP (e.g., there are over 300 ethnic groups which reside in Indonesia alone), cultural and social norms in the region, as in many other regions, perpetuate the notion that violence against children and IPV is a private issue. In many countries, the relatively low status of children in societies and families, where children are perceived as “belonging to” and “in debt toward” their parents and caretakers, and where victims of violence are discouraged from speaking out and obtaining external support, violence is often not publicly discussed or reported, and thus often remains invisible (World Health Organization, 2009). This in addition to other community and societal risk factors such as a tolerance of violence, gender and social inequality in the community, lack of services to support families and institutions and to meet specialized needs, high levels of unemployment, poverty, and inadequate policies and programs within institutions, make the occurrence of child maltreatment more likely (WHO & ISPCAN, 2006).

However, while some social and cultural norms may support or even encourage violence against children, particularly under the guise of child rearing and discipline, it must be emphasized that many social and cultural norms within the region do exist, which promote protective behaviors and practices that are crucial to preventing violence and fostering child resiliency. Such behaviors and practices include community-based structures and networks that facilitate strong social cohesion and inclusiveness; shared responsibility for child care within extended families; and home visitation initiatives by community health volunteers, which have the potential to help strengthen early attachment and reduce the risk of parental violence against young children (Pinheiro, 2006).

Strategies for preventing child maltreatment must aim to reduce these underlying causes and risk factors and strengthen protective factors, and in so doing will prevent the occurrence of new instances of maltreatment. Although most of the scientific knowledge on the effectiveness of such strategies comes from high-income countries, an understanding of how these interventions confront the underlying causes and risk factors can help in designing interventions for low-income and middle-income countries (WHO & ISPCAN, 2006).

Routine data collection on child maltreatment, or surveillance, must be based on accepted, standardized definitions of child maltreatment, so that categories are uniform and sets of data can be effectively compared. Where data are collected in the low- and middle-income countries in the region, they are often not recorded in complete, consistent, or transparent ways. Furthermore, when surveillance systems are in place, they are often not utilized to inform decision-making or child protection policies, programs, and fiscal budgeting. There is an urgent need for more investment in developing and strengthening national child protection information systems across the region. While surveillance is important, it will still miss a large number of incidents of child maltreatment that go unreported and undetected. Wherever possible, surveillance systems should be supplemented by population-based surveys (WHO & ISPCAN, 2006). Good analysis and interpretation of the data gathered—both population-based and case-based—and appropriate presentation and dissemination of the results, are necessary in order for action on child maltreatment to be effective.

While some countries in the region have some elements of child protection systems already in place, other countries in the region have no formal or functional systems. The development of such systems would provide more comprehensive and longer term solutions to protecting children who are already at risk of harm as compared to reactive, single-issue approaches. These systems would require political will and commitment to ensure the response to and the necessary sanctions against violations of children’s rights to protection.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although gaps still exist in our understanding of the outcomes of child maltreatment on children in the EAP region, we do have a growing body of evidence that tells us that the consequences are profound and far-reaching both for children and for the larger community and society. What the data do tell us is that there are significant adverse health and social outcomes resulting from child maltreatment in the region. As such, there is an urgent need for more investment in developing and strengthening national child protection systems across the region in order to provide comprehensive and effective interventions for children already experiencing harm, and primary and secondary interventions to mitigate risks and prevent child maltreatment before it occurs.

sec.title: Implications for Practice, Policy, and Research

list-item.p: The findings indicate that there is an urgent need for governments, civil society organizations, development agencies, and academia to advocate for, invest in, and collaborate across sectors for the strengthening of child protection systems in the EAP Region, with a focus on evidence-based child maltreatment prevention policies and programs.

Countries in the region need to invest in effective surveillance systems coupled with population-based research to better understand the nature and magnitude of child maltreatment and to develop effective interventions.
Practitioners and policy makers need to understand the cumulative effect of violence on children’s lives.

There is a need to focus both on prevention initiatives to stop child maltreatment before it occurs and at the same time on the development of effective responses and interventions to lessen the consequences to children who have already experienced maltreatment.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors would like to acknowledge the Regional Advisory Committee, which was brought together by UNICEF EAPRO for the purpose of developing a regional costing model on the minimum lifetime costs of child maltreatment. This review constitutes the first stage in the development of that model. The Regional Advisory Committee provided technical guidance, comments, and suggestions at various stages of the work. The authors would like to give credit especially to Dr. Alexander Butchart and Mr. Chris Mikton from the World Health Organization, and Dr. Michael Dunne from the Queensland University of Technology, in addition to other members of the committee: Ms. Kateryna Maynzyuk and Mr. Yuriy Dzhygyr from FISCO Inform LLC; Mr. Guy Thompstone and Ms. Shelley Casey from Child Frontiers; M. Phaedra Corso from the University of the Georgia; Prof. M. Ramesh from the University of Hong Kong; and Mr. Mahesh Patel and Ms. Natcha Chutinthararuk from UNICEF EAPRO. Many thanks also to the individuals who helped translate the journal articles presented in this article, specifically Jiandong (Hansen) Sun for translations from Chinese to English and Sohoon Lee for translations from Korean to English. This allowed for the inclusion of many articles previously inaccessible to English-speaking audiences.
